content:
Hello everyone,

It's time for the @WG-governance meeting! React/Reply with :wave: to indicate your attendance. Todays agenda can found in the hackmd, and I've also pasted it below.

  • Project Group RFC
  • Pre-RFC RFC
  • Domain WG Retrospective

In addition there is a new RFC by @nikomatsakis about a "Major Change Process" for the compiler team. https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2904
Pre-RFC pre-RFC, in some sense :D
Hi everyone, I'm a bit slow, be here in 2 minutes
Hi
I'll be pretty quiet today, not feeling so awesome.

I'll start with a Project Group RFC update. I've made a lot of progress and most of the feedback has been addressed. There is still one or two things. One of which that I thought would be worth discussing is defining the role of "lead"/"shepherd".
I've been feeling like I'm eating a bowl of Alphabet soup with only the letters "R" "F" and "C" in it
I think it's probably a good idea to try to define the term :)
For some context here is the original definition of a sub-team lead from the original governance RFC. https://forge.rust-lang.org/governance/index.html#subteams
We've had a fair amount of discussion on this in other topics
We still also have a notion of liaison in the RFC, right?
Yes
So I guess the key thing is to define those two roles
And perhaps to bikeshed about the term "shepherd" vs "lead" :)
It sounds like the shepherd and lead can be the same person sometimes, but sometimes not
I don't think that's right
In particular, I don't think shepherd/lead are different things?
Ok, so they should be two different people, yes?
But maybe you meant liaison?
shepherd & liaison can be the same person sometimes, but a shepherd "is" a lead
aha
I.e. we would either use the term shepherd or the term lead, but they refer to the same role
ty for clarifying - I was getting confused too :)
welcome!
Re: bikeshedding, I like the term "shpeherd" because, to me, it implies "guidance" rather than authority
So what are the responsibilities of the shepherd?
i think shepherd makes me think of more temporary positions

In my view the role is:

  • liaison -- a team member that is encouraging the work. They may or may be that directly involved, but they should generally be "more or less up to date" on what's happening and able to represent the work in meetings. They should also look out for when this might intersect other things happening in the team that are beyond the working group itself.
also because of this comic: https://i.pinimg.com/originals/10/1b/21/101b2173a16abc64aa3dd08b52ea55aa.jpg

my understanding:

  • liason: a team member in the PG
  • shepherd: someone who is doing non-trivial work in the PG
  • lead: the leading shepherd who is... leading the PG (so cyclic... heh)

• shepherd(s) -- they are doing the day to day leading. They help to formulate the overall roadmap, ensure that meetings run, and probably draft RFCs and other things. (or at least delegate those tasks)
this clarifies nicely
I think it's more than "someone doing non-trivial work" -- that's probably a (valued) member :)
@nikomatsakis of the PG? I think it would be strange otherwise for someone doing non-trivial work to not be a member :D
important thing: These should be three different people?
and yeah I think liaison and shepherd can be the same person, if someone from the team feels very passionately about a particular item
I agree that a shepherd is more than "doing non-trivial work". In FFI-unwind, Amanieu is probably doing the most "work", but is not a "shepherd" as such.

Val Grimm said:

important thing: These should be three different people?

there are only two :) -- liaison and shepherd (aka lead)
Who is the lead?
If you mean the shepherd/lead of the ffi-unwind pg, it's @BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand)
I believe we would like to settle on using either the term "lead" or the term "shepherd" to describe a role in a wg.
I think something to also clarify is what should happen when there's maybe tension or disagreement between the liaison and the shepherd?
I agree we should settle on one since we can't seem to even have this conversation without confusion heh :)

My impression is that team lead is someone who is involved in the day to day work of the team, and also liases upwards. A liason is not involved in the day to day work of the team and is instead a parent team member whose responsibility it is to check in
s/team/project-group/, @Manish Goregaokar ?
I think both models are useful; the dev tools team has some WGs without leads and we basically check in with them and they're fine
I thought lead & shepherd were different roles; with there being potentially many shepherds
@Manish Goregaokar Or at least is not "required" to be part of day-to-day-work
@BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand) precisely
On FFI-unwind we have two shepherds; @acfoltzer is the other one.

XAMPPRocky said:

I think something to also clarify is what should happen when there's maybe tension or disagreement between the liaison and the shepherd?

this is a good question, maybe good to clarify a bit more what you mean
So Liason is Niko, and Lead is Amanieu
He's had less time so far to do work for the group, but I consider him a "partner" lead alongside myself - I would say we are both either "shepherds" or "leads".
I am confused @centril -- are you implying that lead and shepherd are two distinct roles?

as clippy team lead, i actually review clippy PRs and do clippy work. As someone who occasionally liases with the rustfmt and rustup WGs, i do not review PRs or make decisions under normal circumstances, however i talk to the people who do
@nikomatsakis that's my read of what the RFC says
(both sub-WGs have leads so it's not a perfect comparison, but this would work even without leads)

centril said:

that's my read of what the RFC says

OK. I don't believe that's intended, but @XAMPPRocky can clarify.
Yes that's not intended.
@Manish Goregaokar seems right, and I think that e.g. if there were an issue that needed clarification from team, they might come to you to say "hey how should we deal with this"

XAMPPRocky said:

I think something to also clarify is what should happen when there's maybe tension or disagreement between the liaison and the shepherd?

I would say:

  • document the disagreements with the pros & cons
  • discuss with the wider PG
  • bring it to the "parent" team (e.g., T-Lang)

Looks to me like the main part implying that leads/shepherds are different is:

  • Archival can be started by the project group shepherds, the liasion, or the lead(s) of
    the parent team if needed.

https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2856/files#diff-540621c0421522b9b3f25d2ad9860531R104
For the record - we're talking about the shepherd/liason roles in project groups, not in the pre-RFC process
Correct
Although they are the same terms that I used in that post

I think @centril's points are fine for a technical disagreement. I think it's also possible that we find that either:

  • liaisons are not able to really "do their role"
  • or the same for shepherds
and/or they just don't work well together
I think this should get kicked up to team lead to mediate, and core team can help out :)

But there is also this:

Project Groups are led by "Shepherds".
Yeah that also makes sense, in more extreme circumstances
So, here's the thing
(much like other disagreements)
we're trying to describe a current
slightly chaotic reality
I would propose that the term "lead" (where it refers to a leadership role for a wg) be changed to "shepherd" throughout the doc
which it is hard to come up with
consistent definitions based on

nikomatsakis said:

I think this should get kicked up to team lead to mediate, and core team can help out :slight_smile:

(actual decisions would continue through FCP and team consensus process and whatnot, though)
(but you mention it's less about the technical)
Do you mean like "technical decisions"? I agree, those are always made through FCP process etc
so maybe instead it would be better to start with what needs to be done, be clear about what that is and how it should be segmented, have say the list of responsibilities as it was in that forge doc
Or vice-versa, changing "shepherd" to "lead". I think "shepherd" encourages a certain mindset, but "lead" may be more intuitive.
"lead" feels more "there's one person" to me btw

Do these definitions still fit?

  • liaison -- a team member that is sponsoring the work. They may or may be that directly involved, but they should check-in periodically and be able to represent the work in meetings. They should also look out for when this might intersect other things happening in the team that are beyond the working group itself. They are a point of contact for the group to ask questions as well.
  • shepherd(s) or lead(s) -- they are doing the day to day leading. They help to formulate the overall roadmap, ensure that meetings run, that the work of the group is transparent through blog posts or summaries, and probably draft RFCs and other things. (Or at least delegate those tasks)
vs. "shepherds" as several people feels more natural
Before we bikeshed the term shepherd vs lead
i do not like using the term shepherd used for this
we have already used it very strongly to mean a more just-in-time thing of temporary leadership
hold that topic I want to see if we have consensus on the definitions :)
i mean, this is a comment on the definition, it does not signify day to day leading to me
"Organizer"?
substitute "lead" in your head if it helps
oh okay, is the question a def for shepherd/lead?
anyway I think we do...?
yeah in that case that makes sense
yes
sorry, i misunderstood
Seems everyone is happy about the definitions
Some bikeshed necessary though? :P
OK, great, let's talk about the term shepherd/lead
h/o I have a comment
the only thing I'd consider adding is that leads are, in my mind, responsible for overall "wg transparency"
I previously expressed this as "shepherds should produce periodic summaries" but that's too concrete/implementation-focused
I adopted the term Shepherd because I see the role as "guiding" the design and conversation. But I don't feel very strongly. I am ok with lead.
Maybe we'll repurpose the term shepherd in some other context :)

nikomatsakis said:

OK, great, let's talk about the term shepherd/lead

"shepherd" doesn't feel descriptive; it doesn't imply "you are doing lotsa organizing", and "lead" doesn't necessarily either
Personally I think I have a preference for "lead", because it reduces the overall number of terms/jargon. I agree with the intent behind shepherd.

BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand) said:

the only thing I'd consider adding is that leads are, in my mind, responsible for overall "wg transparency"

ooh, this is good
I would suggest a third term: coordinator (yes, I googled synonyms for "organizer")

the transparency aspect is important because w/out specifying that this is the responsibility of the lead/coordinator/shepherd/organizer/project-manager, it could otherwise fall to the liaison, who, as a member of a Rust team such as lang, is probably over-burdened anyway
(I added some notes about transparency)
I prefer the term "lead" to "coordinator" or "organizer",
I personally prefer "lead" or "shepherd" above "coordinator" or "project manager"
in part because I think that part of the role is likely to be .. hmm .. somewhat more than just "putting things in order"
it's also got an element of steering to it, I think, helping to move things towards consensus and a good result
@Manish Goregaokar I think the just-in-time aspect may not be a problem? Project groups, in particular, are not intended to last forever
anyway I mostly think @XAMPPRocky is right about fewer terms
if we don't use the term lead,
my impression of shepherds is that they're facilitators not leaders
people will use it anyway
( as we've seen in this meeting :) )
resulting in confusion
@BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand) just-in-time as in _very_ short time periods, shepherds are per-rfc
That's kind of how I view my role as a shepherd, though. As I mentioned above, I don't view the shepherd role as necessarily having much "authority"
hmmmm
also yeah +++1 to erin's point
I'm :thumbs_up: on "Lead"
@Manish Goregaokar is that just because of how the term has been used w/in the Rust org, or something inherent to the word "shepherd" in your mind?
(I have no strong preference for anything)
As a quick time check we've reached half way through our time. Should we move on? It seems like we've hit a general consensus but I want to be sure.
I still prefer "shepherd", but I think that even if we adopt "lead" we can reconsider changing it to "shepherd" at a later date.
Okay, so that brings us to the next topic, pre-rfcs @Nell Shamrell-Harrington
Cool
I started work on a pre-rfc rfc https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2904/files
but it is in very early draft form now
@Nell Shamrell-Harrington wrong link?
gah
https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-governance/pull/47/files
There is also a notes page in that PR trying to consolidate points from various conversations in various meetings

there are a couple of points that need clarifying - one (similar to our conversation for the last 30 min) is clarification of what the role of "shepherd" and "liason" are in the context of the pre-rfc process
First note is that the lead (nee shepherds)/liaisons terms are the same as the ones we were just discussed

i'm a bit wary of formalizing the pre-rfc process; in my experience the pre-rfc process exists _explicitly to sidestep formalization_ and have a low-overhead way of getting feedback on concrete proposals
two - this seems like something we should try with one team before trying to come up with a standard process for all teams
this doesn't mean that we shouldn't have this process, i'm just pointing out that this will not replace pre-rfcs as they exist today
it might be a branding issue but
oh sorry nell is still talking
nah, I'm done for now
but ty!
(Zulip add "xxx is typing" when)
might be a nice feature request, yeah...
discuss away!
so, I agree that there is still value to posting a pre-RFC on an internals thread without a lot of hoopla
I also think of the pre-RFC process as a sort of filter for the teams... You have a very unbaked idea? Internals will give you some feedback and the proposal might get shot down quickly
or it might be found to be something very clever / good / interesting, and should be developed further

So what I think is that this can just be an upgraded verson of the existing pre-rfcs. It's definitely written that way in nell's draft!

As in, you can make a pre-rfc with zero overhead the way you do today, but you can also ask for a shepherd/etc. Team members are encouraged to ask "hey do you want a shepherd/etc for this rfc" on pre-rfcs

I think the things I would like from some process are:

  • first, to have a way for people to get help in drafting RFCs, and to lighten that load. I've heard from plenty of folks that the process as it exists is kind of scary, and that it encourages you to (e.g.) open a "fully fledged" RFC that might, indeed, just not be something people are all that interested in at all.

Here are the things I think we can gain from a semi-formalized "process":

  • earlier buy-in: people won't write a whole RFC only to have the relevant team say "we will not pursue this in any form"
  • guidance (the original "shepherding" idea, which AFAIK isn't actually being used in practice)
  • less churn once the RFC PR is opened
Er, I guess most of that was already said while I was typing
• second, a more focused set of "open PRs" against the RFC repo. I basically think we should onlyl have a PR there once there is some member of the lang team actively serving as a liaison

Team members are encouraged to ask "hey do you want a shepherd/etc for this rfc" on pre-rfcs

Btw, this is something I find happens
(perhaps too frequently for my taste)
I think that asking for folks to join in on threads is "ok" but not quite enough
I also feel like there shouldn't be an expectation

One problem I have with the current situation is that pre-rfcs are kind of forgotten until someone posts their version. I don't know how many crates.io pre-RFCs have started with someone writing their own RFC and then quickly told there have been 4 or 5 pre-rfcs for the feature already.

centril said:

(perhaps too frequently for my taste)

That's interesting. What is the downside of that happening "too" frequently?
that is, I'd like a way for people to have "open requests", and I think it's on the team to review thsoe, but sometimes things will sit for a long time in this state, and that's ok
(because there's only so much bandwidth)
/me goes back to re-read everyone else's comments :)
@BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand) a language team seeking to produce too many designs I think; and especially when there's an imbalance in team member distribution re. "hey do you want a shepherd"

I agree with @Manish Goregaokar that it would be totally possible (and probably good) if the very first step is just "open a thread", and then at some point, when you feel the thread is ready, maybe you open the issue that points us at the thread (or I think it's also ok to open the issue first).

sometimes things will sit for a long time in this state, and that's ok

The problem currently, I think, is that the open PR page on the RFC repo is not a great place for many such requests to "sit for a long time"
Yes, I agree with that.
(What I'm saying could totally be a non-issue for other teams btw; just relaying how I feel about the lang team)

@centril Oh - hm. I think that's actually part of what we're trying to solve here. It shouldn't be so much that people are "offered" shepherds (especially by random commenters who aren't volunteering to _be_ a shepherd), but that people are encouraged to _find_ shepherds before proceeding.
I.e. "this proposal should have a shepherd" should itself be a limiting factor
It should, sometimes, imply "this proposal needs to wait until team resources are freed up"
here is my attempt to start making a "flowchart" :)
https://hackmd.io/0aXUYmS5Q7e4XoxBzpyAbQ
my assumption re: leads is that generally speaking the person opening the issue is also volunteering to "lead"
(I'm switching from shepherd to "lead", per our earlier conversation)
I just added a few more nodes :)
i like this
Even for small proposals, I think it may be worthwhile to at least encourage (if not mandate) that the RFC be drafted in stages, collaboratively.

It should, sometimes, imply "this proposal needs to wait until team resources are freed up"

We could do better at communicating our bandwidth, as it will still be work to handle incoming requests even if they won't be completed.
Yes so
I think this is mildly out of scope, maybe, but maybe not..

I.e. I'd break the "AuthoRFC" node down a bit:

  • Open collaborative RFC-draft document and communication chanel (e.g. Zulip/Discord/Slack, up to author & liaison)
    • It is okay for proposals to get "stuck" here for a while!
  • Authors agree to post PR
  • Standard RFC process ensues (starting w/ PR)
    • We want to avoid proposals getting "stuck" here
I would like to see e.g. lang team expressing a kind of mapping
like "here are the members and the things they are serving as liaison for"
plus "here are the kinds of things they like to liaison"
the idea being that be seeing people's "queues"
it's clearer what the bandwidth is
in any case I definitely think we should try to be clearer about that, and I think we'd find it really useful also for communicating to each other what we're trying to work on
sweet - this gives me more to work with when revising the draft :)
(we've been taking some baby steps and I've found it useful, personally)
Question now (which we can take up next week) is what team should try out the process first
I agree, @BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand), and I also agree that once it is time to start authoring the RFC, I think the distinction ebtween "project group" and "active project" might be slim --
the lang team comes to mind for me - since they are already doing a lightweight pre-rfc process

in compiler team and elsewhere I was drawing this distinction of a project vs a project group. The idea being that every project group is also a project, but for some projects, there isn't all a real "group" around it, just a channel and a few folks communicating.

@nikomatsakis I like that. This is definitely out of scope, but I've thinking about having some kind of general contribution page that better directs people towards efforts that are actively looking for contributors and work.

nikomatsakis said:

I agree, BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand), and I also agree that once it is time to start authoring the RFC, I think the distinction ebtween "project group" and "active project" might be slim --

I think the difference is that project groups _require_ some things that are probably optional in the general case:

  • Dedicated chat channel
  • Dedicated repository

Nell Shamrell-Harrington said:

the lang team comes to mind for me - since they are already doing a lightweight pre-rfc process

yeah I was assuming that we'd start with lang team and try to encourage others to adopt over time
I do think eventually we should try to "consolidate" this
note that the compiler team MCP that I just proposed is actually quite similar to this
@nikomatsakis btw, after "stabilize features", consider having some sort of "maintain features, fix bugs, etc." (e.g. wg-async-foundations)
cool - I will revise the draft and come back with a new one next week for us to discuss at the next meeting
ty, all, this was very helpful :)
though I don't think I realized just how similar it was until just now

@centril yes. In #t-compiler/wg-meta recently, we were talking about the distinction between projects and areas -- the idea being that major projects often turn into areas of the compiler that need to be maintained afterwards
/giphy dirk gently everything is connected
actually now that I think about it, the MCP thing in some sense is this process
slighty tweaked in that it's engineered to allow "small things" to just go through with some advertisement
which probably applies to lang team too, honestly
for small tweaks yeah
yeah, I mean sometimes we have proposals like "we should implement this trait for that type" or whatever
although that is harder to assess for language design; things which are trivial to impl might also be super easy to have opinions on
interesting
So does it merit merging the two efforts? I think most teams also want to let in small changes and advertise it.
well I think we might tweak it a bit but the idea of "float the idea in this way and let team try to assess which path is needed afterwards" seems fine
@nikomatsakis hmm, impl traits for a type as a lang thing?

XAMPPRocky said:

So does it merit merging the two efforts? I think most teams also want to let in small changes and advertise it.

that's what I'm wondering. It seems to me that it does.
@centril ok maybe not best example, anyway you know what I mean tho
@nikomatsakis let's assume I don't... I might not, actually :slight_smile:
unless it's "small tweak" in general, then sure
all I'm saying is that we sometimes make small decisions, often on PRs, and sometimes we push that further up, requesting an RFC, or at least a write-up, etc
yes, just the general idea of "small tweaks don't even merit RFCs sometimes"
yeah, ok, I know what you mean
I think the basic idea is same on compiler team, but the ratio of requests using each path is different
anyway @XAMPPRocky to echo your point from earlier, I think having the same terminology for these things is very useful

one of the things I wanted to do on the compiler team was to create a flow chart ("so you want to do X" was my working title) that would guide people on the process for each kind of thing they might want to do
it probably looks quite similar to that hackmd
Okay real quick we have 2 minutes left.
(with some more stuff, e.g., often it will just be "open a PR")
well I guess the conclusion is that Nell and I can put our heads together on MCP vs "pre-rfc" etc
@nikomatsakis I'd be interested in collaborting w/ you on such a flowchart
So for next time, I'm thinking we have the same topics, though I would expect project group rfc just to be a status update.
Seems reasonable. We didn't talk much about domain WGs.

that ties into something I wanted to mention as a possible future meeting topic: I asked @dpc about how easy it is to "scale" the triage team, b/c for people looking for "ways to contribute" to Rust (who don't have specific things they want to do), that seems like a promising candidate

We discussed it very briefly in the core team meeting, I think the logic next step is probably trying to write-up the notes from before, and maybe have a conversation about what people are really looking for when they think about forming a domain WG
@BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand) see also #t-compiler/wg-prioritization
So I think at some point it would be good to discuss "how do newcomers get involved"
Okay that's the meeting everyone! Thanks for attending! :wave:
but yes, I'd love to have a "master flow chart" for the whole project
:wave:
Is anyone willing to write the update post for the "Inside Rust" on the meeting for the "Inside Rust" blog?
I can do it
Thank you @Nell Shamrell-Harrington :slight_smile:
I was just recently watching BSG
one of my all time favorites :)
alright, got to go get things ready for our new little foster bunny who is arriving in about half an hour - ty all!

Pull request with the blog post is up! https://github.com/rust-lang/blog.rust-lang.org/pull/562
